DataElement.preferredName: Patient Monoclonal Antibody Infusion Hypersensitivity Personal Medical History Ind-2
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the yes/no indicator whether a patient's personal medical history of hypersensitivity, an exaggerated response by the immune system to an infusion of monocolonal antibody, an antibody produced by a clone or genetically homogenous population of hybrid cells i.e., hybridoma; hybrid cells are cloned to establish cell lines producing a specific antibody that is chemically and immunologically homogeneous.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Patient Monoclonal Antibody Infusion Hypersensitivity Personal Medical History
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the patient's personal medical history of hypersensitivity, an exaggerated response by the immune system to an infusion of monocolonal antibody, an antibody produced by a clone or genetically homogenous population of hybrid cells i.e., hybridoma; hybrid cells are cloned to establish cell lines producing a specific antibody that is chemically and immunologically homogeneous.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A person who requires medical care.

Concepts.definition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.

Property.preferredName: Monoclonal Antibody Infusion Hypersensitivity Personal Medical History
Property.preferredDefinition: An antibody produced by a clone or genetically homogenous population of hybrid cells i.e., hybridoma; hybrid cells are cloned to establish cell lines producing a specific antibody that is chemically and immunologically homogeneous. They are widely used in cancer detection, diagnosis and treatment.:A method of putting fluids, including drugs, into the bloodstream. Also called intravenous infusion.:An exaggerated response by the immune system to a drug or other substance.:an account of all medical events and problems a person has experienced.

Concepts.definition: An antibody produced by a clone or genetically homogenous fast-growing cells i.e., hybridoma. Hybridoma cells are cloned to establish cell lines producing a specific antibody that is chemically and immunologically homogeneous. They are widely used in cancer detection, diagnosis, and treatment.
Any form of treatment that is introduced into the body via a blood vessel, a muscle, or the spinal cord.
An exaggerated response by the immune system to a drug or other substance.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.

ConceptualDomain.preferredName: Chronic or Associated Diseases and Exposures
ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: chronic diseases, as well as diseases and exposures associated with cancer.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The preferred Value Domain to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 2022.12.28 Alt VM added per ticket request CADSR0001837. aj

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The affirmative response to a question.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual domain that includes value meanings to be used for Indicator Value Meanings such as Yes, No, Unknown, No Applicable

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A caDSR representation term that is used to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no

Concepts.definition: A response or indicator that can have a value of either yes or no.

ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient have history of clinically significant allergic reaction to prior monoclonal antibody therapy

ReferenceDocuments.description: Does the patient have a history of severe hypersensitivity reaction to any monoclonal antibody?

ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have a history of severe hypersensitivity (>=Grade 3) reaction to a monoclonal antibody?

ReferenceDocuments.description: Prior allergic reactions attributed to other monoclonal antibodies
